◆ bufrdeco_parse_f2_compressed()

int bufrdeco_parse_f2_compressed ( struct bufrdeco_compressed_data_references *  r,
struct bufr_descriptor *  d,
struct bufrdeco *  b 
)

parse a descritor with f = 2 in case of compressed bufr

Parameters
rpointer to a struct bufrdeco_compressed_data_references where to set data references if any
dpointer to the source descriptor
bpointer to the base struct bufrdeco

If succeded return 0, otherwise 1

Definition at line 318 of file bufrdeco_f2.c.

319{
320 size_t nbits;
321 uint32_t ival;
322 struct bufrdeco_compressed_ref *rf;
323 uint8_t has_data;
324
325 if ( d->f != 2 )
326 {
327 return 0; // nothing to do here
328 }
329
330 switch ( d->x )
331 {
332 case 1:
333 // Add (YYY–128) bits to the data width given for each
334 // data element in Table B, other than CCITT IA5
335 // (character) data, code or flag tables.
336 if ( d->y )
337 {
338 b->state.added_bit_length = d->y - 128;
339 }
340 else
341 {
342 b->state.added_bit_length = 0;
343 }
344 break;
345
346 case 2:
347 // Add YYY–128 to the scale for each data element in
348 // Table B, other than CCITT IA5 (character) data, code
349 // or flag tables.
350 if ( d->y )
351 {
352 b->state.added_scale = d->y - 128;
353 }
354 else
355 {
356 b->state.added_scale = 0;
357 }
358 break;
359
360 case 3:
361 // Subsequent element descriptors define new reference
362 // values for corresponding Table B entries. Each new
363 // reference value is represented by YYY bits in the Data
364 // section. Definition of new reference values is concluded
365 // by coding this operator with YYY = 255. Negative
366 // reference values shall be represented by a positive
367 // integer with the left-most bit (bit 1) set to 1.
368 b->state.changing_reference = d->y;
369 break;
370
371 case 4:
372 // Precede each data element with YYY bits of
373 // information. This operation associates a data field
374 // (e.g. quality control information) of YYY bits with each
375 // data element.
376 b->state.assoc_bits = d->y;
377 break;
378
379 case 5:
380 // YYY characters (CCITT International Alphabet No. 5) are
381 // inserted as a data field of YYY x 8 bits in length.
382 nbits = 8 * d->y;
383 rf = & ( r->refs[r->nd] );
384 if ( get_bits_as_char_array ( rf->cref0, &rf->has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), nbits ) == 0 )
385 {
386 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_parse_f2_compressed(): Cannot get %u uchars from '%s'\n", d->y, d->c );
387 return 1;
388 }
389 strcpy ( rf->name, "SIGNIFY CHARACTER" );
390 strcpy ( rf->unit, "CCITTIA5" ); // unit
391
392 // Is suppossed all data will have same length in all subsets
393 // extracting inc_bits from next 6 bits
394 if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &ival, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), 6 ) == 0 )
395 {
396 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_parse_f2_compressed(): Cannot get 6 bits for inc_bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
397 return 1;
398 }
399 if ( ival != d->y )
400 {
401 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_parse_f2_compressed(): Bad length in inc_bits for a 2 05 YYY descriptor from '%s'\n", d->c );
402 return 1;
403 }
404 rf->inc_bits = ival;
405 b->state.bit_offset += rf->inc_bits * 8 * b->sec3.subsets;
406 if ( r->nd < ( BUFR_NMAXSEQ - 1 ) )
407 {
408 r->nd += 1;
409 }
410 else
411 {
412 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_parse_f2_compressed(): Reached limit. Consider increas BUFR_NMAXSEQ\n" );
413 return 1;
414 }
415 break;
416
417 case 6:
418 // YYY bits of data are described by the immediately
419 // following local descriptor.
420 b->state.local_bit_reserved = d->y;
421 break;
422
423 case 7:
424 // For Table B elements, which are not CCITT IA5
425 // (character data), code tables, or flag tables:
426 // 1. Add YYY to the existing scale factor
427 // YYY
428 // 2. Multiply the existing reference value by 10
429 // 3. Calculate ((10 x YYY) + 2) ÷ 3, disregard any
430 // fractional remainder and add the result to the
431 // existing bit width.
432 if ( d->y )
433 {
434 b->state.added_scale = d->y;
435 if ( d->y < 10 )
436 b->state.factor_reference = pow10pos_int[d->y];
437 else
438 {
439 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_parse_f2_compressed(): Too much %u increase bits for operator '%s'", d->y,
440 d->c );
441 return 1;
442 }
443 b->state.added_bit_length = ( int8_t ) ( ( 10.0 * d->y + 2.0 ) / 3.0 );
444 }
445 else
446 {
447 b->state.added_scale = 0;
448 b->state.factor_reference = 1;
449 b->state.added_bit_length = 0;
450 }
451 break;
452
453 case 8:
454 // YYY characters from CCITT International Alphabet
455 // No. 5 (representing YYY x 8 bits in length) replace the
456 // specified data width given for each CCITT IA5
457 // element in Table B.
458 b->state.fixed_ccitt = d->y;
459 break;
460
461 case 22:
462 // Quality information follows
463 // The values of Class 33 elements which follow relate to
464 // the data defined by the data present bit-map.
465 //
466 // Here we jsut activate the quality_active flag
467 b->state.quality_active = 1;
468 b->state.subs_active = 0;
469 b->state.retained_active = 0;
470 b->state.stat1_active = 0;
471 b->state.dstat_active = 0;
472 break;
473
474 case 23:
475 if ( d->y == 0 )
476 {
477 // Substituted operator values
478 //
479 // The substituted values which follow relate to the data
480 // defined by the data present bit-map.
481 b->state.quality_active = 0;
482 b->state.subs_active = 1;
483 b->state.retained_active = 0;
484 b->state.stat1_active = 0;
485 b->state.dstat_active = 0;
486 }
487 break;
488
489 case 24:
490 if ( d->y == 0 )
491 {
492 // First-order statistical values follow
493 //
494 // The statistical values which follow relate to the data
495 // defined by the data present bit-map.
496 b->state.quality_active = 0;
497 b->state.subs_active = 0;
498 b->state.retained_active = 0;
499 b->state.stat1_active = 1;
500 b->state.dstat_active = 0;
501 }
502 break;
503
504 case 25:
505 if ( d->y == 0 )
506 {
507 // Difference statistical values follow
508 //
509 // The statistical values which follow relate to the data
510 // defined by the data present bit-map.
511 b->state.quality_active = 0;
512 b->state.subs_active = 0;
513 b->state.retained_active = 0;
514 b->state.stat1_active = 0;
515 b->state.dstat_active = 1;
516 }
517 break;
518
519 case 32:
520 if ( d->y == 0 )
521 {
522 // Replaced/retained values follow
523 //
524 // The replaced/retained values which follow relate to the
525 // data defined by the data present bit-map.
526 b->state.quality_active = 0;
527 b->state.subs_active = 0;
528 b->state.retained_active = 1;
529 b->state.stat1_active = 0;
530 b->state.dstat_active = 0;
531 }
532 break;
533
534
535 case 35:
536 // Cancel backward data reference
537 //
538 // This operator terminates all previously defined backward
539 // reference and cancels any previously defined
540 // data present bit-map; it causes the next data present
541 // bit-map to refer to the data descriptors which
542 // immediately precede the operator to which it relates.
543
544 // Set the bitmap pointer to NULL.
545 b->state.bitmap = NULL;
546 break;
547
548 case 36:
549 // Define data present bit-map
550 //
551 // This operator defines the data present bit-map which
552 // follows for possible re-use; only one data present
553 // bit-map may be defined between this operator and the
554 // cancel use defined data present bit-map operator.
555
556 // Here we just add a bufrdeco_bitmap struct set the current bitmap
557 if ( bufrdeco_allocate_bitmap ( b ) )
558 {
559 // Cannot allocate another bitmap
560 return 1;
561 }
562 // Set the new current bitmap
563 b->state.bitmap = b->bitmap.bmap[b->bitmap.nba - 1];
564
565 // Now set the bitmaping backward count to 1 to flag that next replicator descriptor must be set it properly
566 b->state.bitmaping = 1;
567
568 break;
569
570 case 37:
571 // if y = 0000 use defined data present bit-map
572 // This operator causes the defined data present bit-map to be used again.
573 //
574 // if y = 255 Cancel use defined data present bit-map
575 // This operator cancels the re-use of the defined data present bit-map.
576 if ( d->y == 0 )
577 {
578 if ( b->bitmap.nba && b->state.bitmap == NULL )
579 b->state.bitmap = b->bitmap.bmap[b->bitmap.nba - 1];
580 }
581 else if ( d->y == 255 )
582 {
583 b->state.bitmap = NULL;
584 }
585 break;
586
587 default:
588 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_parse_f2_compressed(): Still no proccessed descriptor '%s' in "
589 "current library version\n", d->c );
590 return 1;
591 }
592 return 0;
593}
bufrdeco_allocate_bitmap
int bufrdeco_allocate_bitmap(struct bufrdeco *b)
Definition: bufrdeco_memory.c:318
pow10pos_int
const int32_t pow10pos_int[10]
Definition: bufrdeco_tableb.c:30
bufr_sec3::subsets
uint32_t subsets
Definition: bufrdeco.h:603

◆ bufrdeco_parse_f2_descriptor()

int bufrdeco_parse_f2_descriptor ( struct bufrdeco_subset_sequence_data *  s,
struct bufr_descriptor *  d,
struct bufrdeco *  b 
)

parse a descritor with f = 2

Parameters
spointer to a struct bufrdeco_subset_sequence_data where to set data if any
dpointer to the source descriptor
bpointer to the base struct bufrdeco

If succeded return 0, otherwise 1

Definition at line 35 of file bufrdeco_f2.c.

36{
37 size_t nbits;
38 struct bufr_atom_data *a;
39 uint8_t has_data;
40
41 if ( d->f != 2 )
42 {
43 return 0; // nothing to do here
44 }
45
46 switch ( d->x )
47 {
48 case 1:
49 // Add (YYY–128) bits to the data width given for each
50 // data element in Table B, other than CCITT IA5
51 // (character) data, code or flag tables.
52 if ( d->y )
53 {
54 b->state.added_bit_length = d->y - 128;
55 }
56 else
57 {
58 b->state.added_bit_length = 0;
59 }
60 break;
61
62 case 2:
63 // Add YYY–128 to the scale for each data element in
64 // Table B, other than CCITT IA5 (character) data, code
65 // or flag tables.
66 if ( d->y )
67 {
68 b->state.added_scale = d->y - 128;
69 }
70 else
71 {
72 b->state.added_scale = 0;
73 }
74 break;
75
76 case 3:
77 // Subsequent element descriptors define new reference
78 // values for corresponding Table B entries. Each new
79 // reference value is represented by YYY bits in the Data
80 // section. Definition of new reference values is concluded
81 // by coding this operator with YYY = 255. Negative
82 // reference values shall be represented by a positive
83 // integer with the left-most bit (bit 1) set to 1.
84 b->state.changing_reference = d->y;
85 break;
86
87 case 4:
88 // Precede each data element with YYY bits of
89 // information. This operation associates a data field
90 // (e.g. quality control information) of YYY bits with each
91 // data element.
92 b->state.assoc_bits = d->y;
93 break;
94
95 case 5:
96 // YYY characters (CCITT International Alphabet No. 5) are
97 // inserted as a data field of YYY x 8 bits in length.
98 nbits = 8 * d->y;
99 a = & ( s->sequence[s->nd] );
100 memcpy ( &a->desc, d, sizeof ( struct bufr_descriptor ) );
101 if ( get_bits_as_char_array ( a->cval, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), nbits ) == 0 )
102 {
103 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_parse_f2_descriptor(): Cannot get %u uchars from '%s'\n", d->y, d->c );
104 return 1;
105 }
106 if ( has_data == 0 )
107 {
108 a->mask |= DESCRIPTOR_VALUE_MISSING;
109 }
110 else
111 {
112 a->mask |= DESCRIPTOR_HAVE_STRING_VALUE;
113 }
114 strcpy ( a->name, "SIGNIFY CHARACTER" );
115 strcpy ( a->unit, "CCITTIA5" ); // unit
116 if ( s->nd < ( s->dim - 1 ) )
117 {
118 ( s->nd ) ++;
119 }
120 else if ( bufrdeco_increase_data_array ( s ) == 0 )
121 {
122 ( s->nd ) ++;
123 }
124 else
125 {
126 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_parse_f2_descriptor(): No more bufr_atom_data available. Check BUFR_NMAXSEQ\n" );
127 return 1;
128 }
129 break;
130
131 case 6:
132 // YYY bits of data are described by the immediately
133 // following local descriptor.
134 b->state.local_bit_reserved = d->y;
135 break;
136
137 case 7:
138 // For Table B elements, which are not CCITT IA5
139 // (character data), code tables, or flag tables:
140 // 1. Add YYY to the existing scale factor
141 // YYY
142 // 2. Multiply the existing reference value by 10
143 // 3. Calculate ((10 x YYY) + 2) ÷ 3, disregard any
144 // fractional remainder and add the result to the
145 // existing bit width.
146 if ( d->y )
147 {
148 b->state.added_scale = d->y;
149 if ( d->y < 10 )
150 b->state.factor_reference = pow10pos_int[d->y];
151 else
152 {
153 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_parse_f2_descriptor(): Too much %u increase bits for operator '%s'", d->y,
154 d->c );
155 return 1;
156 }
157 b->state.added_bit_length = ( int8_t ) ( ( 10.0 * d->y + 2.0 ) / 3.0 );
158 }
159 else
160 {
161 b->state.added_scale = 0;
162 b->state.factor_reference = 1;
163 b->state.added_bit_length = 0;
164 }
165 break;
166
167 case 8:
168 // YYY characters from CCITT International Alphabet
169 // No. 5 (representing YYY x 8 bits in length) replace the
170 // specified data width given for each CCITT IA5
171 // element in Table B.
172 b->state.fixed_ccitt = d->y;
173 break;
174
175 case 22:
176 // Quality information follows
177 // The values of Class 33 elements which follow relate to
178 // the data defined by the data present bit-map.
179 //
180 // Here we jsut activate the quality_active flag
181 b->state.quality_active = 1;
182 b->state.subs_active = 0;
183 b->state.retained_active = 0;
184 b->state.stat1_active = 0;
185 b->state.dstat_active = 0;
186 break;
187
188 case 23:
189 if ( d->y == 0 )
190 {
191 // Substituted operator values
192 //
193 // The substituted values which follow relate to the data
194 // defined by the data present bit-map.
195 b->state.quality_active = 0;
196 b->state.subs_active = 1;
197 b->state.retained_active = 0;

199 b->state.dstat_active = 0;
200 }
201 break;

206 // First-order statistical values follow
207 //
208 // The statistical values which follow relate to the data
209 // defined by the data present bit-map.
210 b->state.quality_active = 0;
211 b->state.subs_active = 0;
212 b->state.retained_active = 0;

227 b->state.retained_active = 0;
228 b->state.stat1_active = 0;
229 b->state.dstat_active = 1;
230 }
231 break;

240 b->state.quality_active = 0;
241 b->state.subs_active = 0;
242 b->state.retained_active = 1;
243 b->state.stat1_active = 0;
244 b->state.dstat_active = 0;
245 }
246 break;
247
248 case 35:
249 // Cancel backward data reference
250 //
251 // This operator terminates all previously defined backward
252 // reference and cancels any previously defined
253 // data present bit-map; it causes the next data present
254 // bit-map to refer to the data descriptors which

266 // bit-map may be defined between this operator and the
267 // cancel use defined data present bit-map operator.
268
269 // Here we just add a bufrdeco_bitmap struct set the current bitmap
270 if ( bufrdeco_allocate_bitmap ( b ) )

272 // Cannot allocate another bitmap
273 return 1;
274 }

276 b->state.bitmap = b->bitmap.bmap[b->bitmap.nba - 1];
277
278 // Now set the bitmaping backward count to 1 to flag that next replicator descriptor must be set it properly
279 b->state.bitmaping = 1;
280
281 break;
282
283 case 37:

286 //
287 // if y = 255 Cancel use defined data present bit-map

◆ bufrdeco_parse_tree()

int bufrdeco_parse_tree ( struct bufrdeco *  b)

Parse the tree of descriptors without expand the replicators.

Parameters
bPointer to the source struct bufrdeco

This is the user function to parse the descriptor structure of a BUFR report. This is the first task we need to perform after read the bufr report with the aid of bufrdeco_read_bufr function.

At the end we will get an array of structs bufr_sequence defining the tree

A sequence layer is needed when parsing expanded descriptor sec3 and sec4

First bufr_sequence is the sequence of descriptors in sec3 after byte 8. This is a bufr_sequence in level 0.

When a sequence descriptor is found in a layer, the sequence entries found in table D form this descriptor is a son bufr_sequence. This son has then a father and also can have one or more sons. The index level is incremented by one every step it go into decendents.

And so we go in a recursive way up to the end.

If success return 0, if something went wrong return 1

Definition at line 150 of file bufrdeco_tree.c.

151{
152 // here we start the parse
153 return bufrdeco_parse_tree_recursive ( b, NULL, NULL );
154}
bufrdeco_parse_tree_recursive
int bufrdeco_parse_tree_recursive(struct bufrdeco *b, struct bufr_sequence *father, const char *key)
Parse the descriptor tree in a recursive way.

struct bufr_atom_data *  a 
)

targetstring where to print the result
apointer to struct ref bufr_atom_data with data to print

Definition at line 353 of file bufrdeco_print.c.

354{
355 char aux[256], *c;
356 size_t nlimit, climit;
357
358 c = target;
359 c += sprintf ( c, "%u %02u %03u ", a->desc.f, a->desc.x, a->desc.y );
360 strcpy ( aux, a->name );
361 aux[64] = '\0';
362 c += sprintf ( c, "%-64s ", aux );
363 strcpy ( aux, a->unit );
364 aux[20] = '\0';
365 c += sprintf ( c, "%-20s", aux );
366 if ( a->mask & DESCRIPTOR_VALUE_MISSING )
367 {
368 c += sprintf ( c, "%17s", "MISSING" );
369 }
370 else
371 {
372 if ( a->mask & DESCRIPTOR_HAVE_STRING_VALUE )
373 {
374 strcpy ( aux, a->cval );
375 aux[64] = '\0';
376 c += sprintf ( c, " " );
377 c += sprintf ( c, "%s", aux );
378 }
379 else if ( a->mask & DESCRIPTOR_HAVE_CODE_TABLE_STRING
380 || strstr ( a->unit, "CODE TABLE" ) == a->unit
381 || strstr ( a->unit, "Code table" ) == a->unit )
382 {
383 strcpy ( aux, a->ctable );
384 aux[64] = '\0';
385 c += sprintf ( c, "%17u ", ( uint32_t ) a->val );
386 c += sprintf ( c, "%s", aux );
387 }
388 else if ( a->mask & DESCRIPTOR_HAVE_FLAG_TABLE_STRING )
389 {
390 strcpy ( aux, a->ctable );
391 aux[64] = '\0';
392 c += sprintf ( c, " 0x%08X ", ( uint32_t ) a->val );
393 c += sprintf ( c, "%s", aux );
394 }
395 else
396 {
397 c += sprintf ( c, "%s ", get_formatted_value_from_escale ( aux, a->escale, a->val ) );
398 }
399
400 }
401
402 // Now print remaining chars in a->name or a->ctable
403 nlimit = 64;
404 climit = 64;
405 while ( ( strlen ( a->name ) > nlimit && nlimit < BUFR_TABLEB_NAME_LENGTH ) ||
406 ( strlen ( a->ctable ) > climit && climit < BUFR_EXPLAINED_LENGTH ) )
407 {
408 aux[0] = 0;
409 if ( strlen ( a->name ) > nlimit && nlimit < BUFR_TABLEB_NAME_LENGTH )
410 strcpy ( aux, a->name + nlimit );
411 if ( strlen ( aux ) > 64 )
412 aux[64] = 0;
413 c += sprintf ( c, "\n %-64s", aux );
414 aux[0] = 0;
415 if ( strlen ( a->ctable ) > climit && climit < BUFR_EXPLAINED_LENGTH )
416 strcpy ( aux, a->ctable + climit );
417 if ( strlen ( aux ) > 64 )
418 aux[64] = 0;
419 c += sprintf ( c, " %s", aux );
420 nlimit += 64;
421 climit += 64;
422 }
423
424 if (a->is_bitmaped_by != 0)
425 c += sprintf(c, " *IS BITMAPED BY #%u*", a->is_bitmaped_by);
426
427 if (a->bitmap_to != 0)
428 c += sprintf(c, " *BITMAP TO #%u*", a->bitmap_to);
429
430 if (a->related_to != 0)
431 c += sprintf(c, " *RELATED TO #%u*", a->related_to);
432
433 return target;
434}
get_formatted_value_from_escale
char * get_formatted_value_from_escale(char *fmt, int32_t escale, double val)

174 {
175 if ( a->is_bitmaped_by != 0 )
176 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='missing'>MISSING</td><td>NOTE: Bitmaped by <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>", ss, a->is_bitmaped_by, a->is_bitmaped_by );
177 else if ( a->bitmap_to != 0 )
178 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='missing'>MISSING</td><td>NOTE: Bitmap to <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>", ss, a->bitmap_to, a->bitmap_to );
179 else if ( a->related_to != 0 )
180 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='missing'>MISSING</td><td>NOTE: Related to <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>", ss, a->related_to, a->related_to );
181 else
182 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='missing'>MISSING</td><td></td>" );
183 }
184 else
185 {
186 if ( a->mask & DESCRIPTOR_HAVE_STRING_VALUE )
187 {
188 if ( a->is_bitmaped_by != 0 )
189 c += sprintf ( c, "<td></td><td class='cval'>%s<br>NOTE: Bitmaped by <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>\n", a->cval, ss, a->is_bitmaped_by, a->is_bitmaped_by );
190 else if ( a->bitmap_to != 0 )
191 c += sprintf ( c, "<td></td><td class='cval'>%s<br>NOTE: Bitmap to <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>\n", a->cval, ss, a->bitmap_to, a->bitmap_to );
192 else if ( a->related_to != 0 )
193 c += sprintf ( c, "<td></td><td class='cval'>%s<br>NOTE: Related to <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>\n", a->cval, ss, a->related_to, a->related_to );
194 else
195 c += sprintf ( c, "<td></td><td class='cval'>%s</td>\n", a->cval );
196 }
197 else if ( a->mask & DESCRIPTOR_HAVE_CODE_TABLE_STRING
198 || strstr ( a->unit, "CODE TABLE" ) == a->unit
199 || strstr ( a->unit, "Code table" ) == a->unit )
200 {
201 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='ival'>%17u</td>", ( uint32_t ) a->val );
202 if ( a->is_bitmaped_by != 0 )
203 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='ctable'>%s<br>NOTE: Bitmaped by <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>\n", a->ctable, ss, a->is_bitmaped_by, a->is_bitmaped_by );
204 else if ( a->bitmap_to != 0 )
205 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='ctable'>%s<br>NOTE: Bitmap to <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>\n", a->ctable, ss, a->bitmap_to, a->bitmap_to );
206 else if ( a->related_to != 0 )
207 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='ctable'>%s<br>NOTE: Related to <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>\n", a->ctable, ss, a->related_to, a->related_to );
208 else
209 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='ctable'>%s</td>\n", a->ctable );
210 }
211 else if ( a->mask & DESCRIPTOR_HAVE_FLAG_TABLE_STRING )
212 {
213 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='hval'>0x%08X</td>", ( uint32_t ) a->val );
214 if ( a->is_bitmaped_by != 0 )
215 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='ctable'>%s<br>NOTE: Bitmaped by <a href='#%du_%u'>#%u</a></td>\n", a->ctable, ss, a->is_bitmaped_by, a->is_bitmaped_by );
216 else if ( a->bitmap_to != 0 )
217 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='ctable'>%s<br>NOTE: Bitmap to <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>\n", a->ctable, ss, a->bitmap_to, a->bitmap_to );
218 else if ( a->related_to != 0 )
219 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='ctable'>%s<br>NOTE: Related to <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>\n", a->ctable, ss, a->related_to, a->related_to );
220 else
221 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='ctable'>%s</td>\n", a->ctable );
222 }
223 else
224 {
225 if ( a->is_bitmaped_by != 0 )
226 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='rval'>%s</td><td>NOTE: Bitmaped by <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>" , get_formatted_value_from_escale ( aux, a->escale, a->val ), ss, a->is_bitmaped_by, a->is_bitmaped_by );
227 else if ( a->bitmap_to != 0 )
228 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='rval'>%s</td><td>NOTE: Bitmap to <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>" , get_formatted_value_from_escale ( aux, a->escale, a->val ) , ss, a->bitmap_to, a->bitmap_to );
229 else if ( a->related_to != 0 )
230 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='rval'>%s</td><td>NOTE: Related to <a href='#d%u_%u'>#%u</a></td>" , get_formatted_value_from_escale ( aux, a->escale, a->val ), ss, a->related_to, a->related_to );
231 else
232 c += sprintf ( c, "<td class='rval'>%s</td><td></td>" , get_formatted_value_from_escale ( aux, a->escale, a->val ) );
233 }
234 }
235 return target;
236}

◆ bufrdeco_read_buffer()

int bufrdeco_read_buffer ( struct bufrdeco *  b,
uint8_t *  bufrx,
size_t  size 
)

Read a memory buffer and does preliminary and first decode pass.

Parameters
bpointer to struct bufrdeco
bufrxbuffer already allocated by caller
sizesize of BUFR in buffer

This function does the folowing tasks:

  • Splits and parse the BUFR sections (without expanding descriptors nor parsing data)
  • Reads the needed Table files and store them in memory.

Returns 0 if all is OK, 1 otherwise

Definition at line 219 of file bufrdeco_read.c.

220{
221 uint8_t *c;
222 size_t ix, ud;
223
224 // Some fast checks
225 if ( ( size + 4 ) >= BUFR_LEN )
226 {
227 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_buffer(): Buffer provided too large. Consider increase BUFR_LEN\n" );
228 return 1;
229 }
230
231 if ( size < 8 )
232 {
233 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_buffer(): Too few bytes for a bufr\n" );
234 return 1;
235 }
236
237 // check if begins with BUFR
238 if ( bufrx[0] != 'B' || bufrx[1] != 'U' || bufrx[2] != 'F' || bufrx[3] != 'R' )
239 {
240 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_buffer(): bufr file does not begin with 'BUFR' chars\n" );
241 return 1;
242 }
243
244 // check if end with '7777'
245 if ( bufrx[size - 4] != '7' || bufrx[size - 3] != '7' || bufrx[size - 2] != '7' || bufrx[size - 1] != '7' )
246 {
247 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_buffer(): bufe file does not end with '7777' chars\n" );
248 return 1;
249 }
250
251 /******************* section 0 *****************************/
252
253 // we have already checked about begin and end
254
255 // length of whole message
256 b->sec0.bufr_length = three_bytes_to_uint32 ( &bufrx[4] );
257 // check if length is correct
258 if ( b->sec0.bufr_length != ( uint32_t ) size )
259 {
260 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_buffer(): bufr file have %u bytes and it says %u\n",
261 ( uint32_t ) size, b->sec0.bufr_length );
262 return 1;
263 }
264
265 // set bufr edition number
266 b->sec0.edition = bufrx[7];
267
268 if ( b->sec0.edition < 3 )
269 {
270 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_buffer(): Bufr edition must be 3 or superior and this file is coded with version %u\n", b->sec0.edition );
271 return 1;
272 }
273
274 // raw
275 memcpy ( &b->sec0.raw[0], &bufrx[0], 8 );
276
277 /******************* section 1 *****************************/
278 c = &bufrx[8]; // pointer to begin of sec1
279 switch ( b->sec0.edition )
280 {
281 case 3:
282 b->sec1.length = three_bytes_to_uint32 ( c );
283 b->sec1.master = c[3];
284 b->sec1.subcentre = c[4];
285 b->sec1.centre = c[5];
286 b->sec1.update = c[6];
287 b->sec1.options = c[7];
288 b->sec1.category = c[8];
289 b->sec1.subcategory = c[9];
290 b->sec1.subcategory_local = 0; // not in version 3
291 b->sec1.master_version = c[10];
292 b->sec1.master_local = c[11];
293 if ( c[12] > 80 )
294 b->sec1.year = 1900 + c[12];
295 else
296 b->sec1.year = 2000 + c[12];
297 b->sec1.month = c[13];
298 b->sec1.day = c[14];
299 b->sec1.hour = c[15];
300 b->sec1.minute = c[16];
301 b->sec1.second = 0; // not in version 3
302 break;
303 case 4:
304 b->sec1.length = three_bytes_to_uint32 ( c );
305 b->sec1.master = c[3];
306 b->sec1.centre = two_bytes_to_uint32 ( &c[4] );
307 b->sec1.subcentre = two_bytes_to_uint32 ( &c[6] );
308 b->sec1.update = c[8];
309 b->sec1.options = c[9];
310 b->sec1.category = c[10];
311 b->sec1.subcategory = c[11];
312 b->sec1.subcategory_local = c[12];
313 b->sec1.master_version = c[13];
314 b->sec1.master_local = c[14];
315 b->sec1.year = two_bytes_to_uint32 ( &c[15] );
316 b->sec1.month = c[17];
317 b->sec1.day = c[18];
318 b->sec1.hour = c[19];
319 b->sec1.minute = c[20];
320 b->sec1.second = c[21];
321 break;
322 default:
323 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_buffer(): This file is coded with version %u and is not supported\n", b->sec0.edition );
324 free ( ( void * ) bufrx );
325 return 1;
326 }
327 memcpy ( b->sec1.raw, c, b->sec1.length ); // raw data
328 c += b->sec1.length;
329 //print_sec1_info(b);
330
331 /******************* section 2 (Optional) ******************/
332 if ( b->sec1.options & 0x80 )
333 {
334 b->sec2.length = three_bytes_to_uint32 ( c );
335 memcpy ( b->sec2.raw, c, b->sec2.length );
336 c += b->sec2.length;
337 }
338
339 /******************* section 3 *****************************/
340 b->sec3.length = three_bytes_to_uint32 ( c );
341 b->sec3.subsets = two_bytes_to_uint32 ( &c[4] );
342 if ( c[6] & 0x80 )
343 b->sec3.observed = 1;
344 else
345 b->sec3.observed = 0;
346 if ( c[6] & 0x40 )
347 b->sec3.compressed = 1;
348 else
349 b->sec3.compressed = 0;
350
351 // loop of unexpanded descriptors
352 for ( ix = 7, ud = 0; ( ix + 1 ) < b->sec3.length && ud < BUFR_LEN_UNEXPANDED_DESCRIPTOR; ix += 2 )
353 {
354 two_bytes_to_descriptor ( &b->sec3.unexpanded[ud], &c[ix] );
355 if ( b->sec3.unexpanded[ud].f || b->sec3.unexpanded[ud].x || b->sec3.unexpanded[ud].y )
356 ud++;
357 }
358 b->sec3.ndesc = ud;
359 memcpy ( b->sec3.raw, c, b->sec3.length );
360 c += b->sec3.length;
361
362 /******************* section 4 *****************************/
363 b->sec4.length = three_bytes_to_uint32 ( c );
364 // we copy 4 byte more without danger because of latest '7777' and to use fastest exctracting bits algorithm
365 memcpy ( b->sec4.raw, c, b->sec4.length + 4 );
366
367 b->sec4.bit_offset = 32; // the first bit in byte 4
368
369 if ( b->mask & BUFRDECO_USE_ECMWF_TABLES )
370 {
371 if ( bufr_read_tables_ecmwf ( b ) )
372 {
373 return 1;
374 }
375 }
376 else
377 {
378 if ( bufr_read_tables_wmo ( b ) )
379 {
380 return 1;
381 }
382 }
383 return 0;
384}

uint32_t two_bytes_to_uint32(const uint8_t *source)
returns the uint32_t value from an array of two bytes, most significant first

◆ bufrdeco_read_bufr()

int bufrdeco_read_bufr ( struct bufrdeco *  b,
char *  filename 
)

Read bufr file and does preliminary and first decode pass.

Parameters
bpointer to struct bufrdeco
filenamecomplete path of BUFR file

This function does the folowing tasks:

  • Read the file and checks the marks at the begining and end to see wheter is a BUFR file
  • Init the structs and allocate the needed memory if not done previously
  • Splits and parse the BUFR sections (without expanding descriptors nor parsing data)
  • Reads the needed Table files and store them in memory.

Returns 0 if all is OK, 1 otherwise

< pointer to a memory buffer where we write raw bufr file

Definition at line 42 of file bufrdeco_read.c.

43{
44 int aux, res;
45 uint8_t *bufrx = NULL; /*!< pointer to a memory buffer where we write raw bufr file */
46 size_t n = 0;
47 FILE *fp;
48 struct stat st;
49
50 /* Stat input file */
51 if ( stat ( filename, &st ) < 0 )
52 {
53 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_bufr(): cannot stat file '%s'\n", filename );
54 return 1;
55 }
56
57 /* Alloc nedeed memory for bufr */
58 if ( S_ISREG ( st.st_mode ) || S_ISLNK ( st.st_mode ) )
59 {
60 if ( ( bufrx = ( uint8_t * ) calloc ( 1, st.st_size + 4 ) ) == NULL )
61 {
62 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_bufr(): cannot alloc memory for file '%s'\n", filename );
63 return 1;
64 }
65 }
66 else
67 {
68 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_bufr(): '%s' is not a regular file nor symbolic link\n", filename );
69 return 1;
70 }
71
72 /* Inits bufr struct */
73 if ( ( st.st_size + 4 ) >= BUFR_LEN )
74 {
75 sprintf ( b->error, "File '%s' too large. Consider increase BUFR_LEN\n", filename );
76 free ( ( void * ) bufrx );
77 return 1;
78 }
79
80 // Open and read the file
81 if ( ( fp = fopen ( filename, "r" ) ) == NULL )
82 {
83 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_bufr(): cannot open file '%s'\n", filename );
84 free ( ( void * ) bufrx );
85 return 1;
86 }
87
88 while ( ( aux = fgetc ( fp ) ) != EOF && ( int ) n < st.st_size )
89 bufrx[n++] = ( uint8_t ) aux;
90
91 // close the file
92 fclose ( fp );
93
94 res = bufrdeco_read_buffer ( b, bufrx, n );
95 free ( bufrx );
96 return res;
97}

References BUFR_LEN, bufrdeco_read_buffer(), and bufrdeco::error.

Referenced by main().

Here is the call graph for this function:
Here is the caller graph for this function:

◆ bufrdeco_reset()

int bufrdeco_reset ( struct bufrdeco *  b)

Reset an struct bufrdeco to be resed with another bufrfile.

Parameters
bpointer to the target struct

This function must be called when parsing another bufrfile without callimg bufrdeco_close and bufrdeco_init.

◆ bufrdeco_substitute_tables()

int bufrdeco_substitute_tables ( struct bufr_tables **  replaced,
struct bufr_tables *  source,
struct bufrdeco *  b 
)

substitute an struct bufr_tables into a struct bufrdeco

Parameters
replacedPointer where to set the replaced pointer
sourcePointer to a struct bufr_tables
bpointer to the container basic struct bufrdeco

Remember that the struct bufr_tables used in bufrdeco library is the one which pointer is in struct bufrdeco . To avoid problems the struct must be initialized before substituted in this fucntion. Both source and replaced structs are not modified.

This is useful if we do not want to read and parse tables again if the caller has a pool of already readed tables.

Definition at line 109 of file bufrdeco_memory.c.

110{
111 *replaced = b->tables;
112 if ( source == NULL )
113 {
114 // allocate memory for table
115 return bufrdeco_init_tables ( & ( b->tables ) );
116 }
117 else
118 b->tables = source;
119 return 0;
120}

References bufrdeco_init_tables(), and bufrdeco::tables.

Here is the call graph for this function:

◆ bufrdeco_tableb_compressed()

int bufrdeco_tableb_compressed ( struct bufrdeco_compressed_ref *  r,
struct bufrdeco *  b,
struct bufr_descriptor *  d,
int  mode 
)

get data from table B when parsing compressed data references

Parameters
rpointer to a struct bufrdeco_compressed_ref where to set results
bbasic container struct bufrdeco
dpointer to the reference struct bufr_descriptor
modeIf 0 then we are getting the data itself for a descriptor. If mode = 1 then we are dealing with associated bits

If succeeded returns 0. If problem returns 1. If mode = 1 and no associated bits returns -1

Definition at line 230 of file bufrdeco_tableb.c.

231{
232 size_t i;
233 uint32_t ival;
234 uint8_t has_data;
235 struct bufr_tableb *tb;
236 tb = & ( b->tables->b );
237
238 // Reject wrong arguments
239 if ( r == NULL || b == NULL || d == NULL )
240 {
241 return 1;
242 }
243
244 // if mode 1 then we search for associated_bits
245 if ( mode && b->state.assoc_bits == 0 )
246 {
247 // This is not an associated field, return -1
248 return -1;
249 }
250
251 if ( mode )
252 {
253 r->is_associated = 1; // Mark this reference as asociated
254 }
255
256 if ( is_a_local_descriptor ( d ) )
257 {
258 // if is a local descriptor we just skip the needed bits signified by operator 2 06 YYY
259 // we assign ref = 0 and ref0 as readed reserved bits. We also will assume escale = 0
260 memcpy ( & ( r->desc ), d, sizeof ( struct bufr_descriptor ) );
261 r->bits = b->state.local_bit_reserved;
262 r->bit0 = b->state.bit_offset; // OFFSET
263 strcpy ( r->name, "LOCAL DESCRIPTOR" );
264 strcpy ( r->unit, "UNKNOWN" );
265
266 // get bits for ref0
267 if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &r->ref0, &r->has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ),
268 b->state.local_bit_reserved ) == 0 )
269 {
270 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
271 return 1;
272 }
273
274 // and get 6 bits for inc_bits
275 if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &ival, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), 6 ) == 0 )
276 {
277 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get 6 bits for inc_bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
278 return 1;
279 }
280
281 r->escale = 0;
282 r->inc_bits = ( uint8_t ) ival; // set the inc_bits
283 // Update the bit offset
284 b->state.bit_offset += r->inc_bits * b->sec3.subsets;
285 b->state.local_bit_reserved = 0; // Clean the reserved bits
286
287 // All is done for this local descriptor
288 return 0;
289 }
290
291 // build the index for tableB
292 i = tb->x_start[d->x] + tb->y_ref[d->x][d->y];
293
294 // copy the descriptor to reference member desc
295 memcpy ( & ( r->desc ), d, sizeof ( struct bufr_descriptor ) );
296 r->ref = tb->item[i].reference_ori; // copy the reference value from tableB, first from original
297 r->bits = tb->item[i].nbits + b->state.added_bit_length; // copy the bits from tableB
298 r->escale = tb->item[i].scale; // copy the scale from Tableb
299 strcpy ( r->name, tb->item[i].name ); // copy the name
300 strcpy ( r->unit, tb->item[i].unit ); // copy the unit name
301
302 // Add the added_scaled if not flag or code table
303 if ( strstr ( r->unit, "CODE TABLE" ) != r->unit && strstr ( r->unit,"FLAG" ) != r->unit &&
304 strstr ( r->unit, "Code table" ) != r->unit && strstr ( r->unit,"Flag" ) != r->unit )
305 {
306 r->escale += b->state.added_scale;
307 }
308 r->bit0 = b->state.bit_offset; // Sets the reference offset to current state offset
309 r->cref0[0] = '\0'; // default
310 r->ref0 = 0 ; // default
311
312 // check if is changing reference then we change reference value
313 if ( b->state.changing_reference != 255 )
314 {
315 // The descriptor operator 2 03 YYY is on action
316 // get the bits
317 if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &ival, &r->has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), r->bits ) == 0 )
318 {
319 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
320 return 1;
321 }
322
323 // Change the reference value in tableB with value previously readed
324 // (we still have the original value in reference_ori)
325 if ( get_table_b_reference_from_uint32_t ( & ( tb->item[i].reference ), b->state.changing_reference, ival ) )
326 {
327 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_val(): Cannot change reference in 2 03 YYY operator for '%s'\n", d->c );
328 return 1;
329 }
330 strcpy ( r->unit, "NEW REFERENCE" );
331 r->ref = tb->item[i].reference;
332
333 // extracting inc_bits from next 6 bits
334 if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &ival, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), 6 ) == 0 )
335 {
336 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get 6 bits for inc_bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
337 return 1;
338 }
339 // Here is supossed that all subsets will have the same reference change,
340 // so inc_bits must be 0 and no inc data should be present
341 if ( ival )
342 {
343 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Bad format for compressed data when changing reference from '%s'\n", d->c );
344 return 1;
345 }
346 r->ref0 = 0; // here we also assume that ref0 = 0
347 r->inc_bits = 0;
348 return 0;
349 }
350
351 if ( strstr ( r->unit, "CCITT" ) != NULL )
352 {
353 // Case of CCITT string as unit
354
355 if ( b->state.fixed_ccitt != 0 ) // can be changed by 2 08 YYY operator
356 r->bits = 8 * b->state.fixed_ccitt;
357
358 if ( get_bits_as_char_array ( r->cref0, &r->has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), r->bits ) == 0 )
359 {
360 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get uchars from '%s'\n", d->c );
361 return 1;
362 }
363 // extracting inc_bits from next 6 bits
364 if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &ival, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), 6 ) == 0 )
365 {
366 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get 6 bits for inc_bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
367 return 1;
368 }
369 r->inc_bits = ival;
370 r->ref0 = 0;
371
372 // Set the bit_offset after all bits needed by this element in all subsets
373 b->state.bit_offset += r->inc_bits * 8 * b->sec3.subsets;
374
375 // all is done here !!
376 return 0;
377 }
378
379 // is a numeric field, i.e, a data value, a flag code or a code
380 // get reference value
381 if ( mode ) // case of associated field
382 {
383 if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &r->ref0, &r->has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), b->state.assoc_bits ) == 0 )
384 {
385 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get associated bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
386 return 1;
387 }
388 // patch for delayed descriptor: it allways have data
389 if ( is_a_delayed_descriptor ( d ) )
390 r->has_data = 1;
391 }
392 else // case of data
393 {
394 if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &r->ref0, &r->has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), r->bits ) == 0 )
395 {
396 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get the data bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
397 return 1;
398 }
399 // patch for delayed descriptor: it allways have data
400 if ( is_a_delayed_descriptor ( d ) )
401 r->has_data = 1;
402 }
403
404 // extracting inc_bits from next 6 bits for inc_bits
405 if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &ival, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), 6 ) == 0 )
406 {
407 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get 6 bits for inc_bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
408 return 1;
409 }
410 r->inc_bits = ival;
411
412 // if is a delayed descriptor then inc_bits MUST be 0.
413 if ( is_a_delayed_descriptor ( d ) && r->inc_bits )
414 {
415 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Found a delayed descriptor with inc_bits != 0\n" );
416 return 1;
417 }
418 // Set the bit_offset after all bits needed by this element in all subsets
419 b->state.bit_offset += r->inc_bits * b->sec3.subsets;
420
421 return 0;
422}

int get_table_b_reference_from_uint32_t(int32_t *target, uint8_t bits, uint32_t source)
Get an int32_t from bits according with bufr criteria to change the reference of a descritor....

◆ bufrdeco_tableb_val()

int bufrdeco_tableb_val ( struct bufr_atom_data *  a,
struct bufrdeco *  b,
struct bufr_descriptor *  d 
)

Get data from a table B descriptor.

Parameters
apointer to a struct bufr_atom_data where to set the results
bpointer to the basic struct bufrdeco
dpointer to the target descriptor

Return 0 if success, 1 otherwise

Definition at line 433 of file bufrdeco_tableb.c.

434{
435 size_t i, nbits = 0;
436 uint32_t ival;
437 uint8_t has_data;
438 int32_t /*escale = 0,*/ reference = 0;
439 struct bufr_tableb *tb;
440
441 tb = & ( b->tables->b );
442
443 // Reject wrong arguments
444 if ( a == NULL || b == NULL || d == NULL )
445 {
446 return 1;
447 }
448
449 if ( is_a_local_descriptor ( d ) )
450 {
451 // if is a local descriptor we just skip the bits signified by operator 2 06 YYY
452 a->mask = DESCRIPTOR_IS_LOCAL;
453 strcpy ( a->name, "LOCAL DESCRIPTOR" );
454 strcpy ( a->unit, "UNKNOWN" );
455 if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &ival, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), b->state.local_bit_reserved ) == 0 )
456 {
457 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_val(): Cannot get bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
458 return 1;
459 }
460 a->val = ival; // we assume escale = 0 and ref = 0
461 b->state.local_bit_reserved = 0; // Clean the reserved bits
462 return 0;
463 }
464
465 i = tb->x_start[d->x] + tb->y_ref[d->x][d->y];
466
467 memcpy ( & ( a->desc ), d, sizeof ( struct bufr_descriptor ) );
468 a->mask = 0;
469 strcpy ( a->name, tb->item[i].name );
470 strcpy ( a->unit, tb->item[i].unit );
471 a->escale = tb->item[i].scale;
472
473 // Case of difference statistics active
474 if ( b->state.dstat_active )
475 nbits = tb->item[i].nbits + 1;
476 else
477 nbits = tb->item[i].nbits;
478
479 if ( b->state.changing_reference != 255 )
480 {
481 // The descriptor operator 2 03 YYY is on action
482 if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &ival, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), nbits ) == 0 )
483 {
484 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_val(): Cannot get bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
485 return 1;
486 }
487 // Change the reference value
488 if ( get_table_b_reference_from_uint32_t ( & ( tb->item[i].reference ), b->state.changing_reference, ival ) )
489 {
490 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_val(): Cannot change reference in 2 03 YYY operator for '%s'\n", d->c );
491 return 1;
492 }
493 strcpy ( a->unit, "NEW REFERENCE" );
494 a->val = ( double ) tb->item[i].reference;
495 return 0;
496 }
497
498 // case of difference statistics active
499 if ( b->state.dstat_active )
500 reference = - ( ( int32_t ) 1 << ( tb->item[i].nbits ) );
501 else
502 reference = tb->item[i].reference;
503
504 //printf(" escale = %d reference = %d nbits = %lu\n", escale, reference, nbits);
505 if ( strstr ( a->unit, "CCITT" ) != NULL )
506 {
507 if ( b->state.fixed_ccitt != 0 ) // can be changed by 2 08 YYY operator
508 nbits = 8 * b->state.fixed_ccitt;
509
510 if ( get_bits_as_char_array ( a->cval, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), nbits ) == 0 )
511 {
512 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_val(): Cannot get uchars from '%s'\n", d->c );
513 return 1;
514 }
515 if ( has_data == 0 )
516 {
517 a->mask |= DESCRIPTOR_VALUE_MISSING;
518 }
519 else
520 {
521 a->mask |= DESCRIPTOR_HAVE_STRING_VALUE;
522 }
523 return 0;
524 }
525
526 // is a numeric field, i.e, a data value, a flag code or a code
527 // Set associated bits
528 if ( b->state.assoc_bits &&
529 a->desc.x != 31 && // Data description qualifier has not associated bits itself
530 get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &a->associated, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), b->state.assoc_bits ) == 0 )
531 {
532 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_val(): Cannot get associated bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
533 return 1;
534 }
535 else
536 {
537 a->associated = MISSING_INTEGER;
538 }
539
540 if ( strstr ( a->unit, "CODE TABLE" ) != a->unit && strstr ( a->unit,"FLAG" ) != a->unit &&
541 strstr ( a->unit, "Code table" ) != a->unit && strstr ( a->unit,"Flag" ) != a->unit )
542 {
543 // case of numeric, no string nor code nor flag
544 nbits += b->state.added_bit_length;
545 }
546
547 if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &ival, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), nbits ) == 0 )
548 {
549 sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_val(): Cannot get bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
550 return 1;
551 }
552
553 // patch for delayed descriptor: it allways have data
554 if ( a->desc.x == 31 )
555 has_data = 1;
556
557 if ( has_data )
558 {
559 if ( strstr ( a->unit, "CODE TABLE" ) != a->unit && strstr ( a->unit,"FLAG" ) != a->unit &&
560 strstr ( a->unit, "Code table" ) != a->unit && strstr ( a->unit,"Flag" ) != a->unit )
561 {
562 a->escale += b->state.added_scale;
563 reference += b->state.added_reference;
564 if ( b->state.factor_reference > 1 )
565 reference *= b->state.factor_reference;
566 }
567 // Get a numeric number
568 if ( a->escale >= 0 && a->escale < 8 )
569 {
570 a->val = ( double ) ( ( int32_t ) ival + reference ) * pow10neg[ ( size_t ) a->escale];
571 }
572 else if ( a->escale < 0 && a->escale > -8 )
573 {
574 a->val = ( double ) ( ( int32_t ) ival + reference ) * pow10pos[ ( size_t ) ( -a->escale )];
575 }
576 else
577 {
578 a->val = ( double ) ( ( int32_t ) ival + reference ) * exp10 ( ( double ) ( -a->escale ) );
579 }
580
581 if ( strstr ( a->unit, "CODE TABLE" ) == a->unit || strstr ( a->unit, "Code table" ) == a->unit )
582 {
583 ival = ( uint32_t ) ( a->val + 0.5 );
584 a->mask |= DESCRIPTOR_IS_CODE_TABLE;
585 if ( bufrdeco_explained_table_val ( a->ctable, 256, & ( b->tables->c ), & ( tb->item[i].tablec_ref ), & ( a->desc ), ival ) != NULL )
586 {
587 a->mask |= DESCRIPTOR_HAVE_CODE_TABLE_STRING;
588 }
589 }
590 else if ( strstr ( a->unit,"FLAG" ) == a->unit || strstr ( a->unit,"Flag" ) == a->unit )
591 {
592 ival = ( uint32_t ) ( a->val + 0.5 );
593 a->mask |= DESCRIPTOR_IS_FLAG_TABLE;
594
595 if ( bufrdeco_explained_flag_val ( a->ctable, 256, & ( b->tables->c ), & ( a->desc ), ival, nbits ) != NULL )
596 {
597 a->mask |= DESCRIPTOR_HAVE_FLAG_TABLE_STRING;
598 }
599 }
600 }
601 else
602 {
603 a->val = MISSING_REAL;
604 a->mask |= DESCRIPTOR_VALUE_MISSING;
605 }
606
607 return 0;
608}
pow10pos
const double pow10pos[8]
Definition: bufrdeco_tableb.c:31
pow10neg
const double pow10neg[8]
Definition: bufrdeco_tableb.c:32

References bufrdeco_decoding_data_state::added_bit_length, bufrdeco_decoding_data_state::added_reference, bufrdeco_decoding_data_state::added_scale, bufrdeco_decoding_data_state::assoc_bits, bufr_atom_data::associated, bufr_tables::b, bufrdeco_decoding_data_state::bit_offset, bufrdeco_explained_flag_val(), bufrdeco_explained_table_val(), bufr_descriptor::c, bufr_tables::c, bufrdeco_decoding_data_state::changing_reference, bufr_atom_data::ctable, bufr_atom_data::cval, bufr_atom_data::desc, DESCRIPTOR_HAVE_CODE_TABLE_STRING, DESCRIPTOR_HAVE_FLAG_TABLE_STRING, DESCRIPTOR_HAVE_STRING_VALUE, DESCRIPTOR_IS_CODE_TABLE, DESCRIPTOR_IS_FLAG_TABLE, DESCRIPTOR_IS_LOCAL, DESCRIPTOR_VALUE_MISSING, bufrdeco_decoding_data_state::dstat_active, bufrdeco::error, bufr_atom_data::escale, bufrdeco_decoding_data_state::factor_reference, bufrdeco_decoding_data_state::fixed_ccitt, get_bits_as_char_array(), get_bits_as_uint32_t(), get_table_b_reference_from_uint32_t(), is_a_local_descriptor(), bufr_tableb::item, bufrdeco_decoding_data_state::local_bit_reserved, bufr_atom_data::mask, MISSING_INTEGER, MISSING_REAL, bufr_atom_data::name, bufr_tableb_decoded_item::name, bufr_tableb_decoded_item::nbits, pow10neg, pow10pos, bufr_sec4::raw, bufr_tableb_decoded_item::reference, bufr_tableb_decoded_item::scale, bufrdeco::sec4, bufrdeco::state, bufr_tableb_decoded_item::tablec_ref, bufrdeco::tables, bufr_atom_data::unit, bufr_tableb_decoded_item::unit, bufr_atom_data::val, bufr_descriptor::x, bufr_tableb::x_start, bufr_descriptor::y, and bufr_tableb::y_ref.

◆ bufrdeco_tabled_get_descriptors_array()

int bufrdeco_tabled_get_descriptors_array ( struct bufr_sequence *  s,
struct bufrdeco *  b,
const char *  key 
)

starget struct bufr_sequence

keystring in the form FXXYYY which is the key of descriptor we want to find out, F = 3

187}

◆ get_bits_as_char_array()

size_t get_bits_as_char_array ( char *  target,
uint8_t *  has_data,
uint8_t *  source,
size_t *  bit0_offset,
size_t  bit_length 
)

Get a string from an array of bits.

get a sequence of bits in data section 4 from a BUFR reports to get an array of chars

Parameters
targetstring as result
has_dataOutput flags to check whether is missing data. If 0 then data is missing, othewise has data
sourcearray of uint8_t elements. Most significant bit of first element is the bit offest reference
bit0_offsetBit offset
bit_lengthLenght (in bits) for the chunck to extract

If returns the amount of bits readed. 0 if problems. It also update bits_offset with the new bits.

Parameters
targetstring with the resulting array
has_dataif 1 then has data, if 0 what we got is missing data
sourcebuffer of uint8_t which is actually the data section 4.
bit0_offsetbit offset of first bit of first char
bit_lengthnumber of bits to extract. Obviously this will be divisible by 8

If returns the amount of bits readed. 0 if problems. It also update bit0_offset with the new bits.

Definition at line 86 of file bufrdeco_utils.c.

87{
88 size_t i, j, k;
89 size_t nc;
90 uint8_t *c;
91
92 if ( bit_length % 8 )
93 return 0; // bit_length needs to be divisible by 8
94
95 //printf("bit_length=%lu\n", bit_length);
96
97 nc = bit_length / 8;
98 i = ( *bit0_offset ) % 8;
99 k = 8 - i;
100 *has_data = 0; // marc if no missing data is present
101 for ( j = 0; j < nc ; j++ )
102 {
103 c = source + ( *bit0_offset ) / 8;
104 * ( target + j ) = ( *c & biti[i] );
105 if ( i )
106 {
107 * ( target + j ) <<= i;
108 * ( target + j ) |= ( ( * ( c + 1 ) & bitk[i - 1] ) >> k );
109 }
110 if ( * ( target + j ) != -1 )
111 *has_data = 1;
112 //printf("%c", * ( target + j ) );
113 *bit0_offset += 8; // update bit0_offset
114 }
115 * ( target + nc ) = '\0';
116 return bit_length;
117}
biti
uint8_t biti[8]
Definition: bufrdeco_utils.c:27
bitk
uint8_t bitk[8]
Definition: bufrdeco_utils.c:28

References biti, and bitk.

◆ get_bits_as_uint32_t()

size_t get_bits_as_uint32_t ( uint32_t *  target,
uint8_t *  has_data,
uint8_t *  source,
size_t *  bit0_offset,
size_t  bit_length 
)

Read bits from an array of uint8_t and set them as an uint32_t.

Parameters
targetuint32_t pointer where to set the result
has_dataOutput flags to check whether is missing data. If 0 then data is missing, othewise has data
sourcearray of uint8_t elements. Most significant bit of first element is the bit offset reference
bit0_offsetBit offset
bit_lengthLenght (in bits) for the chunck to extract

If bil_length is less than 8 then it uses version 2 get_bits_as_uint32_t2

If returns the amount of bits readed. 0 if problems. It also update bits_offset with the new bits.

Definition at line 178 of file bufrdeco_utils.c.

179{
180 int i;
181 uint8_t *c;
182 uint64_t x;
183
184 if ( bit_length > 32 || bit_length == 0 )
185 return 0;
186
187 if ( bit_length < 8 )
188 return get_bits_as_uint32_t2 ( target, has_data, source, bit0_offset, bit_length );
189
190 *target = 0;
191 *has_data = 0; // marc if no missing data is present
192 c = source + ( *bit0_offset ) / 8;
193 i = ( *bit0_offset ) % 8;
194 x = ( ( uint64_t ) ( *c & biti[i] ) << 32 ) + ( ( uint64_t ) ( * ( c + 1 ) ) << 24 ) + ( ( uint64_t ) ( * ( c + 2 ) ) << 16 ) +
195 ( ( uint64_t ) ( * ( c + 3 ) ) << 8 ) + ( uint64_t ) ( * ( c + 4 ) ); // 40 - i bits
196 x >>= ( 40 - i - bit_length );
197 *target = ( uint32_t ) x;
198 if ( ( 1UL << bit_length ) != ( x + 1UL ) )
199 *has_data = 1;
200
201 *bit0_offset += bit_length; // update bit0_offset
202 return bit_length;
203}
get_bits_as_uint32_t2
size_t get_bits_as_uint32_t2(uint32_t *target, uint8_t *has_data, uint8_t *source, size_t *bit0_offset, size_t bit_length)
Read bits from an array of uint8_t and set them as an uint32_t.

◆ get_table_b_reference_from_uint32_t()

int get_table_b_reference_from_uint32_t ( int32_t *  target,
uint8_t  bits,
uint32_t  source 
)

Get an int32_t from bits according with bufr criteria to change the reference of a descritor. Most significant bit in source is sign.

Parameters
targetint32_t as result
bitsnumber of bits to consider
sourceuint32_T with the data to transform

If success return 0, 1 otherwise

Definition at line 216 of file bufrdeco_utils.c.

217{
218 uint32_t mask = 1;
219 if ( bits > 32 || bits == 0 )
220 return 1;
221
222 if ( bits > 1 )
223 mask = ( ( uint32_t ) 1 << ( bits - 1 ) );
224
225 if ( mask & source )
226 {
227 // case of negative number
228 *target = - ( int32_t ) ( source - mask );
229 }
230 else
231 *target = ( int32_t ) ( source );
232 return 0;
233}

◆ get_wmo_tablenames()

int get_wmo_tablenames ( struct bufrdeco *  b)

Get the complete pathnames for WMO csv table files needed by a bufr message.

Parameters
bpointer for a struct bufrdeco

For WMO files this format is adopted BUFR_XX_Y_Z_TableB_en for table B BUFR_XX_Y_Z_CodeFlag for Code table and Flag table. This is equivalent to table C in ECMWF package BUFR_XX_Y_Z_TableD_en for table D

XX is the Version number of master table used Y is the revision (currently ignored) Z is minor revision (currently ignored)

◆ parse_csv_line()

int parse_csv_line ( int *  nt,
char *  tk[],
char *  lin 
)

Parse a csv line.

Parameters
ntpointer to a integer. On success is the number of items found
tkarray of pointers. Every pointer is a item on success
lininput line which is modified in this routine to be splitted into items

NOTE that input line is modified On success return 0, otherwise -1

Definition at line 83 of file bufrdeco_csv.c.

84{
85 size_t i, j, k = 0, l, latest_char = 0;
86 int flag;
87 char c, caux[CSV_MAXL];
88
89 l = strlen ( lin );
90 if ( l > CSV_MAXL || l == 0 )
91 return -1;
92
93 // copy original string
94 strcpy ( caux, lin );
95
96 flag = CSV_WAIT_ITEM;
97
98 for ( i = 0, j = 0, k = 0; i < l; i++ )
99 {
100 c = caux[i]; // original char
101
102 if ( ( flag & CSV_IS_CITED ) == 0 )
103 {
104 if ( flag & CSV_WAIT_ITEM )
105 {
106 if ( strchr ( CSV_SPACE, c ) != NULL )
107 {
108 lin[j++] = c; // copy to target
109 continue;
110 }
111 else if ( c == CSV_CITE )
112 {
113 lin[j++] = '\0'; // copy to target
114 flag |= CSV_IS_CITED;
115 continue;
116 }
117 else if ( c == CSV_SEPARATOR )
118 {
119 /* item vacio */
120 tk[k++] = lin + j;
121 lin[j++] = '\0';
122 flag = CSV_WAIT_ITEM;
123 continue;
124 }
125 else if ( c == CSV_FINAL )
126 {
127 if ( flag & CSV_FINISHED_ITEM )
128 {
129 *nt = k;
130 return 0;
131 }
132 /* al menos un token, vacio */
133 tk[k++] = lin + j;
134 lin[j] = '\0';
135 *nt = k;
136 return 0;
137 }
138 else
139 {
140 latest_char = j;
141 tk[k] = lin + j;
142 lin[j++] = c;
143 flag = CSV_IS_ITEM;
144 continue;
145 }
146 }
147 else if ( flag & CSV_IS_ITEM )
148 {
149 if ( strchr ( CSV_SPACE, c ) != NULL )
150 {
151 lin[j++] = c;
152 continue;
153 }
154 else if ( c == CSV_SEPARATOR )
155 {
156 lin[latest_char + 1] = '\0';
157 j = latest_char + 2;
158 k++;
159 flag = CSV_WAIT_ITEM | CSV_FINISHED_ITEM;
160 continue;
161 }
162 else if ( c == CSV_FINAL )
163 {
164 lin[latest_char + 1] = '\0';
165 k++;
166 *nt = k;
167 return 0;
168 }
169 else
170 {
171 latest_char = j++;
172 }
173 }
174 else if ( flag & CSV_WAIT_SEPARATOR )
175 {
176 if ( c == CSV_SEPARATOR )
177 {
178 lin[j++] = '\0';
179 k++;
180 flag = CSV_WAIT_ITEM;
181 }
182 else if ( c == CSV_FINAL )
183 {
184 lin[j++] = '\0';
185 *nt = k + 1;
186 return 0;
187 }
188 continue;
189 }
190 }
191 else /* CITED */
192 {
193 if ( flag & CSV_WAIT_ITEM )
194 {
195 tk[k] = lin + j;
196 flag &= ( ~CSV_WAIT_ITEM ); // Clean wait item bit
197 }
198 if ( c == CSV_CITE )
199 {
200 if ( caux[i + 1] == CSV_CITE )
201 {
202 if ( flag & CSV_IS_DOUBLE_QUOTED )
203 {
204 flag &= ( ~CSV_IS_DOUBLE_QUOTED ) ; // Clean double quoted bit
205 lin[j++] = '"';
206 i++;
207 }
208 else
209 {
210 flag |= CSV_IS_DOUBLE_QUOTED;
211 lin[j++] = '"';
212 i++;
213 }
214 continue;
215 }
216 else
217 {
218 lin[j++] = '\0';
219 flag = CSV_WAIT_SEPARATOR;
220 }
221 }
222 else if ( c == CSV_FINAL )
223 {
224 lin[j++] = '\0';
225 *nt = k + 1;
226 return 0;
227 }
228 else
229 {
230 lin[j++] = c;
231 }
232 continue;
233 }
234 }
235 return -1;
236}
CSV_CITE
const char CSV_CITE
Definition: bufrdeco_csv.c:36

#define CSV_IS_ITEM
Definition: bufrdeco_csv.c:28

Definition: bufrdeco_csv.c:34

int two_bytes_to_descriptor ( struct bufr_descriptor *  d,
const uint8_t *  source 
)

set a struct bufr_descriptor from two consecutive bytes in bufr file

Parameters
sourcepointer to first byte (most significant)
dpointer to the resulting descriptor

It resturns 0 if all is OK. 1 otherwise
